awd_titl_txt: SHB: Type I (EXP): Collaborative Research: A Portable Power-Assist Orthosis to Aid Elderly Persons in Locomotion
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a portable power-assist orthosis to address the problems of impaired mobility due to lower-extremity weakness.  This robotic orthosis actively assists the user's joint motion according to his or her motion intent, and thus enables the user to perform certain critical, power-consuming tasks (such as the sit-to-stand motion) independently.  The orthosis is powered with a high-performance actuation approach, namely chemo-fluidic actuation, which combines the high-power-density pneumatic actuators with a high-energy-density monopropellant-based pneumatic supply.  In addition to the new actuation approach, the orthosis also features a new structure and user interface for effective load transfer and easy donning-doffing; and an effective motion control algorithm to enable interactive power assist according to the user's motion intent.  With the portable power-assist orthosis, the users reduce the reliance on the assistance by caregivers, enjoy a significantly improved life quality, and stay physically active to avoid the aforementioned issues associated with the sedentary life style.

This project has broader impact to assistive technologies and can improve mobility of elderly individuals and people suffering from the impaired mobility due to lower-extremity weakness. The project can potentially reduce a considerable amount of physical assistance taking care of these individuals, and the cost of time and manpower in the care. The research of the project is incorporated into education activities by utilizing the rehabilitation robotics as an innovative education medium.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research: A Portable Power-Assist Orthosis to Aid Elderly Persons in Locomotion

The ability to move from a seated position to standing is fundamental to functional independence and quality of life for most individuals. Although the task seems quite ordinary and simple, the mechanics related to accomplishing this movement are quite demanding and requires far more strength than walking or even climbing stairs. This research project is a collaborative effort that incorporates a broad spectrum of expertise to advance the science and technology related to the sit-to-stand task. This brief overview is the early outcomes related to the human interface design elements of the project which will be now be integrated into a system for the first iteration of the power assist orthosis to aid in the sit-to-stand and stand. Eventually, the elderly and other individuals that have lower extremity weaknesses that compromise mobility and function would benefit from such a system. 

One of the key outcomes from this research is the design and development of the orthotic interfaces for interacting with both the knee and the ankle. Plastic shells fabricated from a composite of materials (i.e., carbon fiber) have to withstand high forces from the motor and the user of the orthosis. The “shell-like” sections are the means through which forces are applied directly to the limb and foot segments and therefore must be tolerated and comfortable to the user. Numerous prototype shells were evaluated and tested in the laboratory and led to successful orthotic interface designs. One advanced feature was a shank and foot section that did not extend to the inside of the ankle. By encompassing only the outside and back portions of the leg with an orthotic shell reduces the chance for the user to trip because no clearance issues exist when an individual swings their leg to take a step. Our laboratory tests of prototype’s revealed that the rigidity of the orthotic frame, which the shells are affixed to, must be stiff and robust to maintain efficiency in transferring assistive power to the user. The traditional passive orthotic designs in current practice would appear to be not well-suited for powered applications.

We measured the speed at which individual’s stand-up from a seated position and used these measurements to control and drive the motor for a power-assist orthosis. The tests were conducted in an experimental set-up using a leg model made of aluminum and the results suggest that power assistance was achievable our leg model simulation. This work is continuing with the research collaborator on the project who will now combine the ankle and knee elements and begin testing on human subjects.
